summary:
The Security Council, recalling its previous resolutions on terrorism, reaffirms that terrorism in all its forms and manifestations is a serious threat to peace and security. The Council condemns Al-Qaida and associated individuals, groups, undertakings, and entities for their terrorist acts. 

The Council reaffirms that terrorism cannot be associated with any religion, nationality, or civilization and stresses the need to combat terrorism by all means, in accordance with the Charter of the United Nations and international law. 

The Council expresses concern at the increase in incidents of kidnapping and hostage-taking by terrorist groups and stresses that terrorism can only be defeated by a sustained and comprehensive approach involving all States and international and regional organizations.

The Council emphasizes that sanctions are an important tool in maintaining and restoring international peace and security and urges all Member States to participate actively in maintaining and updating the Consolidated List. 

The Council reminds the Committee to remove expeditiously individuals and entities that no longer meet the criteria for listing and recognizes the challenges to the measures implemented by Member States.

The Council welcomes improvements to the Committee's procedures and the quality of the Consolidated List, and expresses its intent to continue efforts to ensure that procedures are fair and clear.

The Council also welcomes the establishment of the Office of the Ombudsperson and its role in improving fairness and transparency, and reiterates that the measures referred to in paragraph 1 of this resolution are preventative in nature.

The Council welcomes the second review of the United Nations Global Counter-Terrorism Strategy and the creation of the Counter-Terrorism Implementation Task Force (CTITF) and encourages further engagement with the CTITF to ensure overall coordination and coherence in the counter-terrorism efforts of the UN system. 

The Council welcomes the continuing cooperation between the Committee and INTERPOL, the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, and all other UN bodies.
